formatted_address: 44 Holland Green, Diversion Canal Wetlands, Singapore 276167
name: Man-made Cascading Water

reviews.text: The short walk from King Albert Park to this area is really nice. The overall area is very pleasant, especially for a walk in the late afternoon when the sun is not so bright. I definitely recommend it for those who just want to walk without needing a map or navigation.

Man-made cascading water refers to a type of artificial waterfall or water feature designed to mimic the natural flow of water in a waterfall. These features are often used in landscaping, urban designs, and garden spaces to create a serene and visually appealing atmosphere. The cascading water is usually directed over multiple steps or tiers, allowing the water to flow down in a series of smaller drops, creating a soothing sound and an aesthetic effect.

Such features are popular in both private and public spaces, including parks, resorts, and courtyards. The cascading effect is not only visually pleasing but also contributes to the ambient soundscape, making it a favorite element in creating peaceful, natural-inspired environments. These water features can be constructed with various materials like stone, concrete, or even glass to enhance the overall design.

A nice spot to have a break after long-distance cycling along the Rail Corridor. You can relax under the nearby shelter and enjoy your drink with the beautiful scenery of the Holland Green Linear Park.

Nice viewing spot to break the otherwise monotonous scenery of the southern part of the the trail. The falls actually are a lot bigger and more impressive in person than in photos, as usual. The spot has an expansiveness to it that is refreshing.
Really cool, walk past it all the time. Not that noisy and fits into the surroundings well
